The development of highly efficient non-sulfide hydrodesulfurization (HDS) catalyst is still an extremely urgent and challenging matter for the ultra-deep HDS of crude oils. Based on the strategy of non-metal doping and incorporation of carbon, Ni2P@C, Ni2Si@C, and NiS2@C catalysts are successfully prepared through temperature-programmed route using MOF-derived Ni@C as precursor and investigated on the HDS of dibenzothiophene. The Ni2P@C sample has the highest HDS performance and the rate constant is 3.890 min−1, which corresponds to a 6-fold enhancement of that over Ni@C catalyst. While the Ni2Si@C catalyst corresponds to a 1.3-fold enhancement of that over Ni@C catalyst. The predictable result for the NiS2@C catalyst is very low HDS activity. There is a charge transfer between Ni and P or Si, which promotes the adsorption and reaction of dibenzothiophene. Moreover, the Ni2P@C catalyst shows outstanding stability during the long-term reaction after an 80 h. These results indicate that the non-metal doping and incorporation of carbon may be a powerful approach to improve the catalytic activity and improve the durability of catalyst for clean liquid fuels. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nickel phosphide Nickel silicide Nickel sulfide Hydrodesulfurization Dibenzothiophene 1 Introduction In order to meet constantly strengthen environmental regulations, removing organic sulfur from crude oil feedstocks becomes much important in oil refineries to obtain clean transportation fuels [1,2]. The maximal sulfur content in diesel and gasoline for transport is now 10 ppm in most countries and regions, meaning a deletion of 99.99% of the sulfur originally present [3]. This represents that extremely recalcitrant molecules such as thiophene, benzothiophene, dibenzothiophene (DBT), and their alkylated derivatives from petroleum fractions need to be desulfurized [4,5]. In addition, the other heteroatomic compounds in crude oils play an important role on the catalytic performances assign to the electronic reconstruction of active metallic sites depending on the Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi relationship. In general, the electronic environment of d-block metals (Co, Ni, Mo, and W) can be modified by the initiation of light heteroatoms (C, Si, P, S, and F) via the generation of strong covalent bonds, which may present special catalytic properties in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process [6–9]. Alumina-supported CoMoS or NiMoS as traditional HDS catalysts are abroad used in the refining industry, but cannot achieve the goal of deep or ultra-deep HDS, which demands the evolution of more effectual and powerful strange catalysts [10–12]. In addition, the sulfiding agents need to be added in the HDS reaction system to maintain the catalytic activity for traditional sulfides catalysts. However, due to the very pernicious for living organism, these sulfiding agents also lead to environmental problems. Therefore, the development of highly efficient HDS catalysts without adding any sulfiding agents is an extremely urgent and challenging matter for the ultra-deep HDS of crude oils. In recent decades, transition metal phosphides [13,14], silicides [15,16], and carbides [17] as non-sulfided HDS catalysts have been widely explored for deep HDS. Due to the doping of non-metal atoms into the active components, the isolated sites and electronic modification have been created, which may improve the HDS properties and catalyst stability. For instance, Liu group studied the catalytic performance of Ni2P catalyst in the HDS of thiophene. In this work, base on the ligand type effect in the Ni-P bonds, Ni2P catalyst showed a high ability to dissociate both thiophene and hydrogen [18]. In addition to, there is an ensemble effect in the Ni-P catalyst comparing the monometallic Ni catalyst, which reduced the count of active sites but then inhibited deactivation caused by high coverage of the extremely bound S. A homogenous mechanism/interpretation was also observed for the HDS of DBT over nickel silicides. In our previous research, bulk nickel silicides with diverse primary Ni/Si molar ratios (Ni/Si = 2:1, 1:1, and 1:2) as efficient non-sulfided catalysts for the HDS of DBT were explored [15]. As is known to all, alloying or forming of intermetallic is an excellent strategy to enhance the HDS activity. However, there are few reports on the comparison results of the Ni-based catalysts with various non-metal doping, such as P, Si, and S in HDS of sulphur-containing compounds. It is necessary to use the same method and metal precursors to synthesize the nickel-based silicide, phosphide, and sulfide catalysts and bring to light the relationship between microstructure (geometric/electronic) properties and the HDS catalytic performance. In this work, a series of Ni-based catalysts (Ni, Ni2P, Ni2Si, and NiS2) was synthesised by temperature-programmed route using Ni-MOF-74 as metal precursor. Non-metal doping Ni-based catalysts have been used in the HDS of DBT in the fixed-bed reactor to make out the structures and catalytic properties. In addition, the comparison results of the Ni-based catalysts with various non-metal doping have been studied in depth. The high sulphur tolerance of Ni2P@C catalyst has been investigated. This discovery could contribute to broaden horizons in which the metal/p-block effect in the intermetallic compounds (IMCs) can guide us to construct the highly efficient and good sulfur tolerance non-sulfided catalysts for ultra-deep HDS reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of non-metal doping Ni-based catalysts Ni-MOF-74 prepared according to the previous method. The Ni@C was prepared by thermolysis of Ni-MOF-74, in which 0.5 g of Ni-MOF-74 sample was pyrolysis at 600 °C for 4 h under argon atmosphere [19]. 2.1.1 Synthesis of Ni2Si@C catalyst The Ni2Si@C was synthesized by a chemical vapor deposition method. Typically, the organosilane (Cl2Si(CH3)2) as Si source was deposited on an amount of Ni@C sample at 450 °C for 1 h in the quartz tube under H2. Before the catalytic testing, the Ni2Si@C sample was processed in NaOH solution (5 mol·L−1) to etch the presumable SiO x passivation. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Ni2P@C catalyst The Ni2P@C was synthesized via a temperature-programmed route. Typically, 0.1 g of Ni@C precursors and 1.15 g of sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2·H2O) were mixed for 20 min and heated to 300 °C for 2 h under Ar and then washed with DI water to take out the excess phosphate. 2.1.3 Synthesis of NiS2@C catalyst The NiS2@C was synthesized by a temperature-programmed route. Typically, 0.1 g of Ni@C precursor and 1.61 g of sodium thiosulfate pentahydrate (H10Na2O8S2) were mixed homogeneously for 20 min in an agate mortar and then transferred in a quartz-tube reactor to heat at 300 °C for 2 h under Ar. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The metal content was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-RB diffractometer with a Cu Kα1 monochromatized radiation source, operated at 40 kV and 100 mA. The average size of particles was evaluated by the Scherrer formula (see in support information) based on the XRD results. N2 physisorption was implemented for obtaining the BET surface areas, pore volumes, and pore size distributions of the catalysts (approximately 0.1 g) at liquid N2 temperature with an Autosorb iQ automated gas sorption analyzer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed using a Zeiss Sigma SEM from OXFORD instruments company, equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyzer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed using a JEOL JEM 2100F transmission electron microscope. Surface compositions were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) obtained by an ESCALAB250 (Thermo VG, USA) spectrometer with Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation with a power of 150 W. All core-level spectra were referenced as the C 1s neutral carbon peak at 284.6 eV and were deconvoluted into Gaussian component peaks. CO chemisorption was carried out on an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritrics Co.) using CO pulse adsorption under 30°C, which was used to measure the accessibility of metal surface sites (CO/metal = 1). Before measurement, the catalyst was activated in situ for 2 h in a H2 atmosphere at 300°C and purged in flowing He followed by absorption of CO (10% in He) when the furnace was cooled to 30°C. 2.3 HDS of DBT The HDS of DBT was accomplished in a trickle fixed-bed reactor with a high-pressure pump and temperature controller. Before the HDS testing, A 0.1 g sample of passivated catalyst (Ni@C, Ni2P@C and Ni2Si@C) was diluted with 5 mL of quartz sand (60–80 mesh) to achieve isothermal plug-flow conditions. The catalyst was activated in situ in H2 (100 mL/min) at 400°C for 2 h to remove the passivation layer. After activation, the pressure was increased to 3.0 MPa and the temperature decreased to 360°C for the HDS reaction. NiS2@C catalyst was directly used without activation. The HDS tests were conducted at 3 MPa, and the temperature ranged from 260°C to 360°C. The feedstock including 0.3 wt.% DBT, 0.5 wt.% octane (internal standard), and decalin was fed into the HDS system at a certain contact time. The products were identified by a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890F) with a flame ionization detect (FID). The HDS of DBT conducted through the direct desulfurization (DDS) and hydrogenation (HYD) pathway. The selectivity to biphenyl (BP) was considered to the selectivity of DDS, and (1-SelBP) was naturally the selectivity to the hydrogenation (HYD) pathway. The contact time (τ) was evaluated by the formula as: (1) τ = m / Q ρ where m represented the weight of catalyst, Q represented the flow of liquid reactant, and ρ represented the density of the liquid reactant. The rate constant (k) was evaluated by the formula (assuming the first order reaction) as: (2) k = − ln ( 1 − c ) − a τ where c was the DBT conversion, τ was the contact time, and a was the constant. Turnover frequencies (TOFs) of the HDS reaction over the prepared catalysts were calculated from the formula: (3) TOF ( h − 1 ) = ( F × c % × 60 ) / ( n t o t a l × D ) where F (mol) was the moles of reactant, C% was the conversion of reactant, n total was the molar of metal in catalyst, and D was the metal dispersion that calculated from the CO chemisorption. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of non-metal doping Ni-based catalysts The XRD results of the prepared samples are showed in Fig. 1 . The Ni@C derived from the carbonization of Ni-MOF-74 precursor displays a typical Ni-based porous material with high dispersion Ni NPs throughout carbon matrix [19]. There are three normal diffraction peaks at 44.5, 51.8 and 76.4o in the XRD result of Ni@C catalyst. These peaks attribute to (111), (200), and (220) of the structure Ni (JCPDS PDF 04-0850) (Fig. 1) [20]. The Ni-M@C (M = Si, P, and S) samples were prepared by the temperature programming reaction between the Ni@C precursor and dimethyldichlorosilane, sodium hypophosphite, and sodium thiosulfate, respectively. The crystal phases of as-prepared intermetallic samples are also confirmed by XRD patterns. Comparing the JCPDS reference data for orthorhombic Ni2Si (JCPDS PDF 50-0779), hexagonal Ni2P (JCPDS PDF 03-0953), and cubic NiS2 (JCPDS PDF 11–0099), the XRD patterns of Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C, and NiS2@C (Fig. 1) are similar to the standard patterns as well as that previous reports [21,22]. The typical crystal structure of non-metal doping Ni-based catalysts are also displayed in the Fig. 1. Compared with the crystal structures of Ni, the surface atoms of Ni2Si, Ni2P and NiS2 IMCs display that both Ni and light heteroatoms gather with each other in short distances, which may impact the absorption model of DBT and the hydrogenation properties. The frequently ordered distribution of the two elements on IMCs would form interfaces all over the surface, leading to the diverse efficiency for the HDS of DBT. In order to further explore the textural properties of the non-metal doping Ni-based catalysts, N2 sorption isotherms, and the pore size distribution are displayed in Fig. 2 . The isotherms of these catalysts are similar, and display hysteresis behaviour with a typical type IV, indicating that these catalysts are mainly mesoporous, which are furthermore confirmed by the relevant pore size distribution curves. Table 1 shows the surface area of prepared catalysts. Ni@C catalyst possesses the highest SBET values of 299 m2·g−1 and Vmeso values of 0.36 cm3·g−1. Micropores and mesopores are all appear in the Ni@C catalyst. The distribution of micropore size center at 1.4 nm and the distribution of mesopore size is from 2 to 8 nm. The actual nickel content in Ni@C sample is ca. 25.37 at%, that is consistent with document [23]. The SBET values of Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C and, NiS2@C samples are smaller than the value of Ni@C precursor. But the SBET values of Ni2Si@C is less than that of Ni2P@C and NiS2@C, which may be related to that Cl2Si(CH3)2 as gas is more easy to enter the pores to react with Ni@C than NaH2PO2·H2O and H10Na2O8S2 as solid. In contrast to Ni@C and Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C and NiS2@C contains less micropores and generous mesopores, with total pore volume respectively are 0.13 cm3·g−1 and 0.14 cm3·g−1, accompanied with the increased average pore size, which is similar to the previous reports. You et al. prepared the CoP/NC by phosphidation of Co/C and explained the deposited P species block the Co/C pores, which decreased the surface areas of CoP/NC [24]. Using the Scherrer formula based on the XRD results, the average crystallite sizes of the Ni-based catalysts are calculated to be ca. 10–15 nm. Compared with the Ni@C, the particle size of Ni2Si, Ni2P, and NiS2 phase in catalysts did not apparently changed. First of all, it is a favorable way to synthesize non-metal doping Ni@C catalysts by the way using Ni-MOF-74 as precursor. The morphology of Ni-M@C (M = Si, P, S) revealed by SEM images consist of many lump-like domains with homogeneous sizes of 2 μm and are sintered to cloud-like structures, as shows in Fig. 3 . The EDX spectrum of these samples confirm the existence of C, Ni, and non-metal doped elements in the catalysts, which is in accordance with the XRD effect. These characterization results collaboratively confirm the formation of Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C, and NiS2@C. Based on the corresponding elemental mappings, the NPs are highly dispersed throughout all over the sample. In order to investigate the structural properties and the composition distribution, representative TEM images are obtained (Fig. 4 ), which clear show the morphology and topography of the as-prepared Ni@C, Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C, and NiS2@C samples. It is suggested that particles in all the samples are well-dispersed with a narrow size distribution. The average particle sizes are 7.5 nm (Ni), 8.4 nm (Ni2Si), 10.6 nm (Ni2P), and 14.4 nm (NiS2), which are almost in good agreement with the crystallite size results calculated by the Scherrer equation based on the XRD rusults. The (inter) nickel nanoparticles are homogenously distributed on the carbon matrix. There is no aggregation of nanoparticles at high pyrolysis temperatures (600°C), indicating the strong interaction between (inter) nickel nanoparticles and the carbon matrix (Fig. 4b). The HRTEM image (Fig. 4c) clearly shows that the obtained Ni@C NPs are coated by a carbon shell. In Fig. 4e, i, and m, many Ni2Si, Ni2P, and NiS2 nanocrystals and carbon shells can be observed. The Ni-M@C NPs are highly dispersed in the whole samples (Fig. 4f, j and n). Furthermore, the size distribution histograms indicate that the particles size of Ni-M@C IMCs catalysts are slightly bigger than the particles size of Ni@C, which suggests the NPs are grew up during synthesis by secondary heating treatment. As shown in Fig. 4d, the d-spacings are measured to be 2.03 Å, 1.76 Å, and 1.25 Å, which coincide with the (111), (200), and (220) planes of the Ni NPs [25]. The HRTEM image (Fig. 4h) demonstrates that the investigated lattice spacing of NPs is 1.99 Å, which are consistent with the (121) plane of orthorhombic Ni2Si [26]. Similarly, the measured lattice spacing with 2.21 Å, and 2.00 Å are related to the (111) plane of Ni2P, and the (220) plane of NiS2 (Fig. 4h and p) [27,28]. The results are similar with that of XRD analysis, which further evidences the formation of Ni-M@C IMCs catalysts. These pores varies from 1.3 nm to 30.0 nm in the sample (Fig. 2). The result of pore structures achieved by N2 sorption is similar to the pore structures of the TEM results. The HAADF-STEM EDX-elemental mappings of Ni2P@C sample displayed in Fig. 5 a. Ni and P atoms are dispersed well throughout the whole Ni2P@C sample. The purple colour of P and the green colour of Ni represent the distribution of the Ni2P, it is known that the granular object is indeed a crystal of highly crystallized nickel phosphide. The EDX in Fig. 5b confirms the elemental composition and indicates that the mole ratio of Ni/P is close to 2 in Ni2P@C sample. Moreover, the STEM-EDX line-scan curve in Fig. 5c further reveals that the Ni has been interstitially reacted with P atoms to form single-phase Ni2P successfully. All the characterization result of XRD and TEM proved the formation of highly uniform dispersion Ni2P in the carbon matrix. The Ni-M interaction in the catalysts was also characterized by XPS in Fig. 6 . The XPS survey spectra (Fig. 6a) indicates that the Ni-based series catalysts are mainly composed of C, O, Ni, and the doping elements (Si, P, and S), which is in agreement with the SEM-EDX spectrum results. There are three peaks in Ni 2p spectra of Ni@C. The peak at 852.8 eV is attributed to metallic nickel and another two Ni 2p peaks at 855.1 eV and 859.3 eV are assign to nickel oxide and the satellite peak (Fig. 6b). The nickel oxide peak is also observed due to its exposed on the air. There are there peaks at 853.2 eV, 856.3 eV, and 861.5 eV in the Ni 2p3/2 of the Ni2Si@C, which belong to the Ni2Si, NiO x , and Ni satellite peak (Fig. 6c). This result is consistent with the previous report [13,29,30]. The peak at 852.8 eV in the Ni 2p3/2 of the Ni@C shift to 853.2 eV in the Ni 2p3/2 of the Ni2Si@C, which confirms the electron transform between nickel and silicon atoms, furtherly indicates the form the Ni2Si phase. In the Si 2p spectra, the peaks at ca. 103.3 eV and 98.5 eV in the Ni2Si@C sample are attributed to the Si-O x and Ni-Si (Fig. 6d), which indicates the surface oxidation of the nickel silicides NPs [31]. Therefore, the Ni2Si@C sample need to be etched for removing the SiO x passivation before the catalytic testing. The XPS of Ni2P@C catalyst indicates that the binding energy of Ni 2p located at 853.3 eV correspond to Ni δ + in the phase of Ni2P (Fig. 6e) [32]. Due to the oxidation in the exposure for Ni2P@C catalyst, the peak of NiO x species (Ni2+) shows at 857.3 eV [32]. Peak at 862.0 eV assigns to the satellite of the Ni 2p 1/2 [33]. In the P 2p spectrum (Fig. 6f), the peak locates at 130.3 eV can be attributed to Pδ− (0 <δ< 1) breeds in the Ni2P. Moreover, due to the deep oxidation of the Ni2P NPs, another peak at 134.3 eV can be attributed to P5+ [32,34,35]. This result is consistent with previous literature [36]. The Ni 2p binding energy in Ni2P is higher than the value for nickel (852.8 eV) and lower than that of nickel oxide (856.3 eV), showing the transport of electron between Ni and P in Ni2P, which indicates that the Ni in Ni2P phase carries a partial positive charge and a partial negative charge carried on P surface. The Ni2P@C catalyst need to be activated for removing the oxidized Ni species by the TPR method in H2 before the HDS testing. The spectral peaks of the Ni 2p can be divided into NiO, NiS2, and its satellite peak in the NiS2@C sample. All peaks of 2p 3/2 at 856.9 eV and 858.8 eV assign to nickel oxide species and nickel sulfide species (Fig. 6g) [37]. Meanwhile, S 2p orbitals of 2p 3/2 (162.8 eV) and 2p 1/2 (164.3 eV) correspond to the S species in NiS2 (Fig. 6h) [38]. After comparison, the XPS spectrum of Ni 2p confirms that the electron transfer between Ni and doping atoms (Si, P, and S) changes the electronic properties of nickel atoms in the prepared catalysts, which is possible to change its catalytic performance. 3.2 Catalytic performance evaluation As-prepared non-metal doping Ni@C catalysts were applied in the HDS of DBT. The the HDS of DBT reaction network shows in Scheme 1 . BP, tetrahydrodibenzothiophene (THDBT), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB), and bicyclohexyl (BCH) are the four main products. The detailed nomenclatures show in the supplementary information. BP is achieved by the DDS pathway and all other products (THDBT, CHB, BCH) are produced through the HYD pathway [21]. Fig. 7 shows the DBT conversion and product selectivity with the range of 260–360 °C over prepared catalysts at the condition of 3 MPa H2 and the contact time of 1.42 min. For all the catalysts, the higher temperature, the DBT HDS activity better. For Ni@C catalyst, the DBT conversion is only 25.7% at 260 °C, while BP, CHB, and BCH are the main target products with a selectivity of 68.4%, 20.9%, and 10.7% (Fig. 7a), respectively. Raise the reaction temperature to 360 °C, the DBT conversion reaches up to 71.4% and the selectivity of BP increased from 68.4% to 91.0%, proving that the Ni-catalyzed C-S bond cleavage by the DDS pathway is enhanced effectively at the higher temperature. The DBT conversion over Ni2Si@C is similar to that over Ni@C (Fig. 7b), which indicates that there is no change the hydrogenation capacity of nickel by doping of Si. The DBT conversion and selectivity to BP also increases by the increased reaction temperature, but the selectivity to BP over Ni2Si@C is minor than the value over Ni@C. For the Ni2P@C catalyst, the conversion of DBT is 35.4% at 260 °C (Fig. 7c), which is higher than that over Ni@C (25.7%) and Ni2Si@C (22.2%). With increasing the temperature from 260 °C to 340 °C, the conversion of DBT is close to 100%. The selectivity to BP over Ni2P@C increases from 260°C to 320°C firstly and then decreases from 320°C to 360°C, the max value (73.1%) achieves at 320°C. For the NiS2@C catalyst, the conversion of DBT is relativity low during the entire temperature range (Fig. 7d). The selectivity to CHB decreases but the selectivity to BP increases with increasing temperature. This result indicates that the DDS is the main pathway over NiS2@C catalyst at the higher reaction temperature in the HDS of DBT. Overall, the HDS activities of non-metal doping Ni@C catalysts present the following order: Ni2P@C > Ni@C ≈ Ni2Si@C > NiS2@C. Assuming pseudo-first-order kinetics for the HDS of DBT, the rate constant k (min−1) was calculated at low conversion, where inhibition by H2S was negligible (Table 2 ). The details of k value acquisition were shown in Fig. S1. The HDS of DBT over Ni2P@C catalyst possesses the highest rate constant of 3.890 min−1, that is 6-fold higher than that over Ni@C. While the k value over the Ni2Si@C catalyst is 1.3-fold higher than that over Ni@C. The rate constant of NiS2@C is equal to that of Ni@C. In addition to, the conversion of DBT over Ni@C, Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C and NiS2@C catalysts are 64.1%, 62.2%, 100%, and 33.8% at the contact time of 1.42 min. Besides, the selectivity to the DDS pathway over Ni@C, Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C, and NiS2@C catalysts are more than 68 % in the HDS reaction. The Ni@C shows a relative higher DDS selectivity (87.3%) in the HDS of DBT. But for metallic Ni catalyst in HDS of DBT, the reactive adsorption is the major desulfurization route. The metallic Ni catalyst quickly transformed to nickel sulfide in the early stage and subsequently inactivated [15]. The DBT consumption rate of these four catalysts are also calculated, as shown in Table 2, which presents the following sequence: Ni2P@C > Ni@C ≈ Ni2Si@C > NiS2@C. The Ni2P@C catalyst shows the highest DBT consumption rate (191.7 nmol·g−1·s−1), while NiS2 catalyst presents the lowest value (64.8 nmol·g−1·s−1). This result indicates NiS2@C catalyst is not good at HDS of DBT. As we all know, MoS2 and WS2 catalysts are conventional sulfide catalyst for HDS, Co or Ni have been widely used as auxiliary [11,12]. The active phase of these catalysts is the so-called Co(Ni)-Mo(W)-S phase. Therefore, the single nickel sulfide has no steep activity in the HDS reaction. In order to precisely understand the activity of the non-metal doping Ni@C catalyst, the TOFs in the HDS of DBT are calculated. The active sites are evaluated by the CO chemisorption, assuming CO/active site = 1. As shown in Table 2, the CO uptakes of Ni2P@C and Ni2Si@C catalysts are decreased comparing with that of Ni@C catalyst due to the non-metal doping. However, the TOF in the HDS of DBT over Ni2P@C (844.7 h−1) is almost 21-fold higher than that of the Ni@C catalyst (40.2 h−1). This evidences further that more active sites are availably exposed in the Ni2P@C catalyst, resulting in the high activity. Based on the effect of non-metal doping on the catalytic activities research, it can be found that the non-metal doping has a great effect on the physical and catalytic activities of Ni-based catalysts. In addition, for the Ni2P@C sample, the Ni atoms has been interstitially modified by P atoms, which is confirmed by the HAADF-STEM and STEM-EDS lines (Fig. 5a and c). The electron transfer between Ni and P would promote the adsorption of DBT and enhance the HDS properties [19]. Hence, both facial active hydrogen and sulphur vacancies of the Ni2P@C catalyst is extended. Simultaneously, the selectivity to HYD route is enhanced, which leads to the excessive hydrogenation of BP owed by enhanced adsorption. Compared with the Ni2Si@C catalyst, the Ni2P@C shows higher catalytic activity by the TOF (168.3 h−1 vs 844.7 h−1), which indicates the P atoms have a stronger modification effect on nickel than that of Si atoms. As we known, the electronegativity of Ni, Si, P atoms is 1.91, 1.90, and 2.19, respectively. The absolute value of electronegativity difference in Ni2Si and Ni2P phases are 0.01 and 0.28, which indicates the adjustment of the nickel electronic and structure properties in Ni2P@C is huger that that of Ni2Si@C. The capacity of active sites obviously increased and further promotes the adsorb of DBT, encouraging the catalytic performance. This amazing achievement is consistent with the previous report about Co-based IMCs (CoIn3 vs CoGa3) [39]. Given all of that, the Ni2P@C catalyst presents the superior HDS activity among all the non-metal doping Ni@C catalysts. In order to further make out the catalytic trait of the prepared catalysts in the HDS of DBT, the products distribution and selectivity as a function of contact time is also investigated, as shown in Fig. 8 . A large amount of DBT is converted to BP over Ni@C catalyst with increased contact time, while the selectivity to BP is almost unchanged (Fig. 8a and b), which indicates that the DDS pathway is main reaction route. However, the geometric and electronic feature of nickel are powerfully decorated by the electron transfer from Ni to non-metal doping atoms (Si, P, and S), which lead to the great change of the products distribution in the HDS of DBT. For the Ni2Si@C catalyst, the selectivity to BP increases slowly from 67.6% to 85.2% with the increased contact time from 0.057 min to 3.79 min (Fig. 8c and d). The increased contact time is conducive to improve the selectivity to DDS pathway. CHB is the second abundant product over Ni2Si@C catalyst. With the increased contact time, the selectivity of CHB decreased from 27.7% to 8.0%. In a contrary, the selectivity of BCH increases from 4.7% to 6.8% with increased contact time. Moreover, the selectivity of THDBT is negligible. Significantly, the DBT conversion over Ni2P@C catalyst obviously increases from 26.5% to 99.0% with increased contact time and the selectivity of BP always stays above 73%, which indicates that the DDS is the predominate pathway over Ni2P@C catalyst. However, when the contact time is 0.057 min, the DBT conversion is only ca. 5.5% and the BP content is 1.9% over NiS2@C catalyst (Fig. 8g). The selectivity of BP increases from 34.8% to 81.2% with increased contact time (Fig. 8h). It can be speculated that the doped non-metal of Ni@C catalysts make a distinction towards the interrelated exhibition for the cleavage of C-S bonds in the HDS reaction. Notably, the HDS of DBT reaction network over nickel-based catalysts becomes clear in Scheme 1. As mentioned above, the properties of non-metal doping Ni@C catalysts are correlative with the doped non-metal elements. Hence, Ni atoms bonding with Si, P, and S atoms can obviously adjust their intrinsic electron arrangement and cause a visible electron transport between Ni and the doped non-metal elements, thus bringing about the alterable Ni@C property. Compared the products distribution and selectivity over the four catalysts, it is further demonstrated that the Ni2P@C catalyst is a promising HDS catalyst for clean liquid fuels. Table 3 reviews the exhaustive comparison results of the Ni2P catalysts published in previous literature in the HDS of DBT for making out the catalytic activity of Ni2P@C [40–63]. The superiority of Ni2P@C catalyst is illustrated by comparing the DBT consumption rate as well as the previous reported Ni2P catalysts. The supported Ni2P catalysts show similar catalytic activity with almost 100% conversion of DBT at the same condition (340 °C and 3.0 MPa H2) except for the Ni2P/SBA-15/cordierite (68.0%), which is clearly higher than the bulk Ni2P activity (62.1%). Due to the differences in substrate concentration and the contact time, the DBT consumption rates of all catalysts are calculated and reflected the catalytic activity of a series Ni2P catalysts. The DBT consumption rate of prepared Ni2P@C in this work is 13.7 times higher than the value of bulk Ni2P. As expected, due to the high specific surface area, Ni2P@C catalyst exposes more active sites to improve adsorption capacity, which is benefit to activate DBT molecules [64]. Furthermore, the activity of Ni2P@C catalyst (191.7 nmol·g−1·s−1) is sharper than that of other supported Ni2P catalysts (Ni2P/SBA-15, Ni2P/Al2O3, and Ni2P/SiO2), except for the Ni2P/MCM-41 catalyst (289.4 nmol·g−1·s−1) for the HDS of DBT at harsh condition (5.0 MPa H2). The as-prepared Ni2P@C catalyst presents fantastic catalytic properties in the HDS of DBT is possible attributed to the existence of carbon species. Firstly, the hierarchical pore carbon with hydrophobic structure could drooped the adsorption of products and boost their transfer, which is favorable to the HDS. This phenomenon is also detected in MoNi/C/TiO2 catalysts [65]. Secondly, due to the Mott-Schottky effect, the electronic density of Ni2P is enhanced by the carbon species, which improved the adsorption capacity and then improve the HDS performance [63–68]. As a potential HDS catalyst, the stability test of Ni2P@C catalyst is conducted at the typical reaction conditions including 340 °C, 3 MPa H2, and 1.42 min of contact time. The time procedure of DBT HDS performance is sustained for 80 h on the Ni2P@C catalyst As shown in Fig. 9 , the DBT conversion is close to 100% in the whole reaction process and no significant change is observed in the prolonged 80 h. The Ni2P@C catalyst displays the high stability. As regards the selectivity, the main product is BP (70%), resulting from the DDS pathway. It is noteworthy that the selectivity to BP is constant throughout the long-time testing. In order to gain further insight into the surface properties of the catalyst after reaction, the spent Ni2P@C catalyst was detected by XPS, as shown in Fig. S2. Interestingly, almost no signal assigned to Ni-P-S species is detected, which is different from the traditional bulk and supported Ni2P catalysts, indicating the sulfur-tolerance of Ni2P@C catalyst [69]. In addition to, the spent Ni@C, NiS2@C and Ni2Si@C catalysts after temperature test were also analyzed by XPS (Fig. S3). Obviously, the Ni-S species are detected in the spent Ni@C and NiS2@C catalysts while no S 2p peak is found in the XPS spectrum of spent Ni2Si@C catalyst. Therefore, the doping elements (P and Si) in the intermetallic (Ni2P and Ni2Si) significantly inhibits the formation of Ni-S bonds, enhancing the sulfur-tolerance in the HDS process, which may be attributed to the non-metal doping effect and the carbon matrix protection effect. 4 Conclusions In summary, non-metal doping Ni@C catalysts (Ni2Si@C, Ni2P@C, and NiS2@C) deriving from Ni-MOF-74 precursor have been prepared by temperature-programmed route and applied in the ultra-deep HDS for clean liquid fuels. The HDS activity of the non-metal doping Ni@C catalysts is as the following sequence, Ni2P@C > Ni@C ≈ Ni2Si@C > NiS2@C. The HDS of DBT over Ni2P@C catalyst possesses the highest rate constant of 3.890 min−1, which is 6-fold higher than of the value over Ni@C catalyst. Significantly, the as-prepared Ni2P@C catalyst presents higher efficient catalytic performance comparing with the previous reported Ni2P catalysts, which can be attributed to the variation of the nickel structure and electronic properties by the P atom in the Ni2P@C, improving the adsorption capacity and promoting the hydrogenation performance. Moreover, the carbon matrix improves the adsorption/activation of DBT by the Mott-Schottky effect and enhances the sulfur resistance of Ni2P@C catalyst. In particular, the as-prepared Ni2P@C catalyst shows outstanding stability over an 80 h test. These results indicate that the as-prepared Ni2P@C catalyst is a promising HDS catalyst for clean liquid fuels. This discovery could contribute to broaden horizons in which the non-metal doping effect can enhance the HDS efficiency and sulfur tolerant of non-sulfided catalysts for ultra-deep HDS reactions. coredata.dc:description: The development of highly efficient non-sulfide hydrodesulfurization (HDS) catalyst is still an extremely urgent and challenging matter for the ultra-deep HDS of crude oils. Based on the strategy of non-metal doping and incorporation of carbon, Ni2P@C, Ni2Si@C, and NiS2@C catalysts are successfully prepared through temperature-programmed route using MOF-derived Ni@C as precursor and investigated on the HDS of dibenzothiophene. The Ni2P@C sample has the highest HDS performance and the rate constant is 3.890 min−1, which corresponds to a 6-fold enhancement of that over Ni@C catalyst. While the Ni2Si@C catalyst corresponds to a 1.3-fold enhancement of that over Ni@C catalyst. The predictable result for the NiS2@C catalyst is very low HDS activity. There is a charge transfer between Ni and P or Si, which promotes the adsorption and reaction of dibenzothiophene. Moreover, the Ni2P@C catalyst shows outstanding stability during the long-term reaction after an 80 h. These results indicate that the non-metal doping and incorporation of carbon may be a powerful approach to improve the catalytic activity and improve the durability of catalyst for clean liquid fuels.
coredata.dc:title: Non-metal doping Ni@C as highly efficient and stable hydrodesulfurization catalysts for clean liquid fuels
